awd_titl_txt: CRII: SaTC: Measuring and Improving the Management of Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI)
awd_abstract_narration:
The Border Gateway Protocol (BGP) is responsible for managing how packets are routed across the Internet by exchanging routing related messages (path announcements) between routers. While the Border Gateway Protocol plays a critical role in the Internet communications, it remains highly vulnerable to many attacks. This is because the protocol was originally designed for each BGP router to trust all protocol related messages, especially path announcements, sent by its neighboring routers. As a result, incorrect and malicious path information would be accepted by routers at face value, potentially leading to destination unreachable problems in the Internet. To address this issue, Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI) was introduced in 2012 to allow routers to verify path announcements in the Border Gateway Protocol. However, today there is a dearth of information available about the vulnerability of the RPKI, and how routers in the Internet have actually deployed and managed it. This project will develop techniques to better understand and improve the management of RPKI, helping to better secure the Internet. Given the early stage of the RPKI protocol, the findings in this project stand a good chance of being integrated to improve the state of the system. The project would train students in related research. The findings of the project would identify what the current security problems of RPKI are and help spur a greater adoption of RPKI by releasing the codes, datasets and analysis tools developed in the project and presenting the research outcomes to other researchers, administrators, and Internet operations related working groups.

This project has two research foci, each examining the management and improving security challenges of the Resource Public Key Infrastructure. First, the project will analyze existing RPKI repositories from multiple vantage points in an effort to understand how much of actual Border Gateway Protocol feeds in the Internet are verifiable. It will also determine what fraction of routers are actually using RPKI to validate paths. For this focus, the investigators will collaborate with one of the biggest network operators that have the most-peered global networks in existence. Second, the project will develop new techniques to detect misconfigurations of routers and potential security vulnerabilities. For this purpose, the project will host a custom RPKI repository that have multiple invalid routes, which will be used to test RPKI validators or routers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Resource Public Key Infrastructure (RPKI) is a service to improve the security of the Internet’s routing infrastructure. In recent years, the publication of Route Origin Authorization (ROA) objects in RPKI, which bind IP prefixes to their legitimate origin ASN, has been rapidly increasing. However, ROAs are effective only if the routers use them to verify and filter BGP announcements, a process called Route Origin Validation (ROV). 
This project was primarily focused on the first part of RPKI, the deployment and management of ROA.  

We published a paper "RPKI is Coming of Age: A Longitudinal Study of RPKI Deployment and Invalid Route Origins" at the ACM Internet Measurement Conference (IMC'19), which was the first comprehensive, longitudinal study of the deployment, coverage, and quality of RPKI.
We used a unique dataset containing all RPKI Route Origin Authorizations (ROAs) from the moment RPKI was first deployed, more than 8 years ago. We combined this dataset with BGP announcements from more than 3,300 BGP collectors worldwide. We measured the RPKI ROA deployment status. We focused the network operators that have published ROA objects to protect their IP prefixes and found prevalent misconfigurations because of misunderstanding of the protocol such as MaxLength. We conclude that while misconfigurations still do occur, RPKI is “ready for the big screen,” and routing security can be increased by dropping invalid announcements. To foster reproducibility and further studies, we released all RPKI data and the tools we used to analyze it into the public domain at https://rpki-study.github.io

Weitong Li, a Ph.D. student at Virginia Tech and had been supported by this grant, extended this work and focusing on the network operators who perform Route Origin Validation (ROV). The prototype of this work is available at https://rovista.netsecurelab.org.

Syed Muhammad Farhan completed his disseration "Exploring the Evolution of the TLS Certificate Ecosystem". The RPKI validation is also based on a certificate, of which structure is similar to certificates in TLS, the most popular application that relies on X.509 certificate. His work will be published at the Passive and Active Measurement (PAM) conference. With this work, we show that a large proportion of invalid certificates still exists and outline reasons why these certificates still exist. Additionally, we report unresolved security issues such as key sharing. Moreover, we show that the incorrect use of template certificates has led to incorrect SCTs being embedded in the certificates. Taken together, our results emphasize the continued involvement of the research community to improve the web’s PKI ecosystem.
